title: If humans established a colony on a distant planet, would it be possible for their descendants to return to Earth? - Quora

response.answer_text: Space is a big place. We know at present of no means by which mass can travel faster than the speed of light—or close to it—about 300,000 km a second. Even at such speeds, it takes 9 minutes just to reach our own sun. It takes years to reach even nearby stars. Your question really is one associated with the value of making visits. If visits are hard and expensive (e.g. like ship voyages were in the 18th century) people will make relatively few of them. It seems terribly unlikely that a long space voyage will ever feel fulfilling and “worth it” when measured in large chunks of available time to live. If these constraints are relaxed, who knows? For now, given what it means to be human and to have human life, it seems very unlikely people would “go home.” Communications might be an entirely different question. Again, for now, we are bound by the speed of light. It is the speed limit of all things except our imagination. Overcome that, and many things can change—as science fiction regularly speculates. Can it be overcome? It seems… unlikely.

If humans colonise another world and then return to Earth several generations later I can see several problems that would need to be considered… lack of resistance to diseases that have evolvedcommunication issues if languages evolve differentlyculture shockI guess that most issues can be easily overcome, but I’m not sure about some of the medical problems that could arise and would appreciate thoughts Thanks!
